{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3022815,"name":"Crossle86","username":"Crossle86","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/crossle86/{size}/6614_2.png","created_at":"2022-03-14T17:21:58.239Z","cooked":"

What connectors do teams like for splicing CAN wires together? We are using crimp style locking hobby connectors which have worked well, but are not so good when it comes to an emergency repair, like we recently experienced.

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":39,"updated_at":"2022-03-14T17:21:58.239Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1152,"reads":636,"readers_count":635,"score":5877.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":405670,"topic_slug":"can-wiring","display_username":"Crossle86","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":19911,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"4450 - Olympia Robotics Federation (Software/Build mentor)"},"post_url":"/t/can-wiring/405670/1","custom_user_title":"4450 - Olympia Robotics Federation (Software/Build mentor)","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null,"can_vote":false},{"id":3022819,"name":"James","username":"otherguy","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/otherguy/{size}/180121_2.png","created_at":"2022-03-14T17:28:20.312Z","cooked":"

There are a few existing threads with lots of info:

The best Can bus connectors Electrical
After years of struggling with our can bus we found These lever nuts on [Amazon](Lever Nut Wire Connectors, 28-12AWG Butt Splice Terminal Wire Connector Box (SPL-2, 28PCS) https://www.amazon.com/dp/B07V4LD144/ref=cm_sw_r_cp_api_glt_fabc_YWYcGb47MC7XD?_encoding=UTF8&psc=1) last year that worked out great. No crimping or Soldering and Still gives you the option to swap components in and out.
Connectors for Star Topology CAN Electrical
This is not a post asking for, nor wanting, advice on the merits of star/loop CAN bus, no gremlins please I‚Äôve been doing a bunch of research into finding a good ‚Äòhub connector‚Äô for a star topology robot, namely something connecting the CAN port on the Rio to all of the other CAN devices. Mostly been looking into pre-existing COTS solutions, but wondering if other teams have found something reliable. [canbus] Something along these lines, where it‚Äôs just a bunch of con‚Ä¶

We use these: https://www.amazon.com/Tyumen-Connectors-Universal-Terminals-Wire-Stripping/dp/B07F3HVQ2Y/ref=pd_rhf_dp_s_pd_crcd_1/138-7614415-3578360,

but I imagine these Wagos from Rev would also work in a pinch: WAGO 221 Inline Splicing Connector - 12 AWG - 50 Pack - REV Robotics

We use these:

https://www.digikey.com/en/products/detail/molex/0050579403/115034

https://www.digikey.com/en/products/detail/molex/0701070002/210969

They take the standard ‚Äúmolex PWM‚Äù contacts and fit into the roborio PWM ports for backwards compatibility. They are keyed so you literally cant connect them backwards. They lock as well. We‚Äôve run them since 2017 and have had no issues so long as they are crimped and strain relieved properly.

In emergency situations we use wago lever nuts but repair when possible.

","post_number":4,"post_type":1,"posts_count":39,"updated_at":"2022-03-14T17:37:56.382Z","reply_count":2,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":10,"reads":539,"readers_count":538,"score":167.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":405670,"topic_slug":"can-wiring","display_username":"Ryan Blue","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://www.digikey.com/en/products/detail/molex/0050579403/115034","internal":false,"reflection":false,"clicks":218},{"url":"https://www.digikey.com/en/products/detail/molex/0701070002/210969","internal":false,"reflection":false,"clicks":94}],"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":29846,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"WPILib Dev | 1024 Mentor"},"post_url":"/t/can-wiring/405670/4","custom_user_title":"WPILib Dev | 1024 Mentor","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3022828,"name":"Allen Nuttle","username":"nuttle","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/nuttle/{size}/124105_2.png","created_at":"2022-03-14T17:36:12.198Z","cooked":"

My personal recommendation is solder and heatshrink when you have the time, with WAGO connectors for quick repairs. WAGO is an option everywhere, but my own sense of things is the overall reliability may suffer over solder/heatshrink ‚Äì provided someone has good soldering skills and exercises care in the electrical construction. Be sure the WAGO connectors you choose are rated for the smaller wire sizes used with CAN, such as these.

We switched from PWM to CAN this year and so far have liked the WCP inline lever nut connectors. They‚Äôre a little bulky but super robust and easy to use.

image695√ó695 37.6 KB

Those molex are what we are using now. Work fine but take time and hard to do when the connector is buried on the robot‚Ä¶hence my question.

Saw these but it seems to me that a connector that can take 12ga wire is too big for CAN wire and the connector would be unnecessarily bulky‚Ä¶?..same for wago 221.

The WCP inline lever nuts look good. Anyone tried the solder seal connectors listed on the same WCP page?

","post_number":9,"post_type":1,"posts_count":39,"updated_at":"2022-03-14T17:48:22.550Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":6,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":446,"readers_count":445,"score":104.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":405670,"topic_slug":"can-wiring","display_username":"Crossle86","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":49816,"username":"_cmb","name":"Charlie Merlynn Becker","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/_cmb/{size}/177172_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":19911,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"4450 - Olympia Robotics Federation (Software/Build mentor)"},"post_url":"/t/can-wiring/405670/9","custom_user_title":"4450 - Olympia Robotics Federation (Software/Build mentor)","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3022900,"name":"philso","username":"philso","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/p/e68b1a/{size}.png","created_at":"2022-03-14T18:33:54.792Z","cooked":"

In the future, design your robot so that all parts of your control system are easily accessible (electrical and pneumatic) since it will make it easier and faster to build and modify/repair. Without a properly working control system, your robot is just a piece of metal art.

","post_number":10,"post_type":1,"posts_count":39,"updated_at":"2022-03-14T18:33:54.792Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":7,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":3,"reads":425,"readers_count":424,"score":145.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":405670,"topic_slug":"can-wiring","display_username":"philso","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":19911,"username":"Crossle86","name":"Crossle86","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/crossle86/{size}/6614_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":3}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":15467,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/can-wiring/405670/10","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":3}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":3,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3023048,"name":"Jim Smith","username":"Rainydaymaker","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/rainydaymaker/{size}/155036_2.png","created_at":"2022-03-14T21:50:12.948Z","cooked":"

2.5mm Pitch JST - SM

","post_number":11,"post_type":1,"posts_count":39,"updated_at":"2022-03-14T21:50:12.948Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":405,"readers_count":404,"score":86.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":405670,"topic_slug":"can-wiring","display_username":"Jim Smith","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":16700,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Jim Smith"},"post_url":"/t/can-wiring/405670/11","custom_user_title":"Jim Smith","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3023063,"name":"bobbysq","username":"bobbysq","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/bobbysq/{size}/195893_2.png","created_at":"2022-03-14T22:10:42.761Z","cooked":"
Crossle86:

Saw these but it seems to me that a connector that can take 12ga wire is too big for CAN wire and the connector would be unnecessarily bulky‚Ä¶?..same for wago 221.

The 221 connectors are kind of bulky for CAN, but the inline ones should be much better. I have some of the larger 10 AWG ones here, and they seem to be working fine with 22 AWG wire and don‚Äôt seem like they would be too much of an issue size-wise.

","post_number":12,"post_type":1,"posts_count":39,"updated_at":"2022-03-14T22:10:42.761Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":8,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":13,"reads":413,"readers_count":412,"score":147.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":405670,"topic_slug":"can-wiring","display_username":"bobbysq","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":28014,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"he/him"},"post_url":"/t/can-wiring/405670/12","custom_user_title":"he/him","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3023069,"name":"Ian2","username":"spacepenguine","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/s/c67d28/{size}.png","created_at":"2022-03-14T22:15:50.356Z","cooked":"

We started to use the generic version (blue/orange) version of these this year in off season to much better success than our previous solutions (mostly molex .1"). It is possible to over-insert wires into the spring-cage connection, which causes flaky connections. To resolve this and make connections more reusable we also use ferrules on the wire ends.

2x2 inline: https://www.amazon.com/Transparent-Connector-Conductor-Splicing-connectors/dp/B09B1QXNXR/
2x4 t-tap: https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B096TLTKPP/
18-22 awg ferrule: https://www.digikey.com/en/products/detail/1241001-1/A110954CT-ND/4142338

Also a quick guide for our team on wire insertion inspection:

Image from iOS (15)1083√ó1245 122 KB

3468 has always done a bus configuration and this year is trying out these lever-nut style T-connectors.

amazon.com

tatoko 10PCS Mini Fast Wire Connector Universal Wiring Cable Connector Push-in...

Feature: 1. Pure copper electrical conductor has good electrical conductivity, low resistivity, electroplated surface to prevent oxidation. 2. The housing is made of flame retardant insulated material, long life,...

Previously we used these crimp-on T-Connectors along with these crimp-on disconnects.

amazon.com

Wire Connectors - TYUMEN 12pcs 2 Pin 2 Way Low Voltage Universal Compact Wire T...

Wire Connectors - TYUMEN 12pcs 2 Pin 2 Way Low Voltage Universal Compact Wire T Tap Connectors, No Wire-Stripping Required, Toolless Wire Connectors, Quick Splice Wire Wiring Connector for AWG 20-24No need to strip...

amazon.com

Pluggable LED Wire Connectors, TYUMEN 24pcs 2 Pin 2 Way Universal Compact Wire...

Pluggable LED Wire Connectors, TYUMEN 24pcs 2 Pin 2 Way Universal Compact Wire Terminals, No Wire-Stripping Required, Toolless Spring Wire Connectors, Quick Splice Wire Wiring Connector for AWG 20-24No need to strip...

The Crimp-On connectors worked great for us, but I was always a bit worried about the ‚Äúwhat if‚Äù of a bad crimp, and how hard it would be to diagnose if one happened. The Connectors were also a bit‚Ä¶ choosy about what thickness of insulation wire they would work with‚Ä¶ The Lever-Nut style ones have the downside of requiring you to cut the ‚Äúbus‚Äù at each connector, but they are easier to add in and you are less prone to bad connections. Both of these solutions have the advantage, to me, over a daisy chain of being able to remove a device from the bus without having to ever break the bus. The crimp-on connectors have the advantage of also not having to break the bus to ADD a device.

We field tested using a CAN Bus configuration where a CAN wire is attached to the RoboRIO and the other end to the Power Distribution Panel CAN ports. Each CAN device was connected to the bus using a T connector

image679√ó679 53.2 KB
(see https://www.amazon.ca/Kalolary-Connectors-Electrical-Connection-Self-Stripping/dp/B07GXJ46K7/ref=asc_df_B07GXJ46K7/ ).

My question is this.

What do we do with the second set of CAN wires?

Could/should we safely cut one set and use the other? Is this advised?

Is there still a likelihood of needing to connect CAN devices in series rather than in parallel? The latter, essentially, is what we get when using a CANBus with T connectors.

","post_number":18,"post_type":1,"posts_count":39,"updated_at":"2022-05-18T16:52:01.075Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":40,"reads":359,"readers_count":358,"score":276.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":405670,"topic_slug":"can-wiring","display_username":"Dr.G","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://www.amazon.ca/Kalolary-Connectors-Electrical-Connection-Self-Stripping/dp/B07GXJ46K7/ref=asc_df_B07GXJ46K7/","internal":false,"reflection":false,"clicks":13},{"url":"https://www.chiefdelphi.com/uploads/default/original/3X/2/a/2aebee2115254c1b365410c333dfdbe91c004561.jpeg","internal":true,"reflection":false,"clicks":0}],"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":33923,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/can-wiring/405670/18","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"thinking","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3062854,"name":"Peter Johnson","username":"Peter_Johnson","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/peter_johnson/{size}/10417_2.png","created_at":"2022-05-18T17:00:18.083Z","cooked":"

CAN isn‚Äôt really serial or parallel, it‚Äôs designed to be a multi-drop bus and allows stubs at each drop. The two sets of CAN wires coming out of the motor controller are directly wired together (literally both ends soldered to the same pad inside the motor controller) so is effectively a ‚ÄúT‚Äù junction inside the motor controller with a very short stub (to the motor controller internals).

So it‚Äôs safe to cut one set, and if you‚Äôre not using it, you should for signal integrity reasons (because otherwise you have a much longer stub that doesn‚Äôt go anywhere).
